page.title: 13LOCAL LANDMARKS
page.content: {Landmarks} are important for the safe navigation of ships. One such landmark is the tower of All Saints and St. Margaret's {Church}, Pakefield. Originally half a mile inland it now stands on the edge of the cliff dur to erosion by the sea. It is some 14 metres high. At G.R. 536 887 stands a derelict {lighthouse}. This was built in 1831 to mark the safe channel between sandbanks off Pakefield and fell into disuse early this century. At G.R. 534 906 is a {water tower}. It was built in the year 1935 to serve the Pakefield area. The top is 33 m. above sea level. Because of poor siting of this tower and continued housing development, another larger water tower was built at G.R. 534 906 in 1957. The top of this tower is 45 m. above sea level.
